div.head: THE ANGLO-EGYPTIAN BANK, LIMITED.
div.p: LONDON, PARIS ALEXANDRIA, CAIRO, MALTA, GIBRALTAR, TANTAH, AND PORT SAID.
The Anglo-Egyptian Bank. Limited,
undertakes every description of banking business on the most favourable conditions.
Current accounts opened with commercial homes and private individuals in conformity with the custom of Bankers.
Fixed deposits for one year certain received at 8 per cent. per annum. Deposits at interest for shorter periods are also received at rates to be agreed upon.
Letters of Credit for the use of travellers are issued payable in all parts of the World.
Approved bills discounted.
Bills, documentary invoices, etc, collected.
Drafts and telegraphic transfers issued payable all over the World.
Foreign exchange bought and sold.
Advances made upon approved securities and upon cotton, cotton-seed, sugar and other merchandise.
The purchase and sale of stocks and shares on the London Stock Exchange; and on the local and Continental Bourses, undertaken.

Customers can deposit their valuables, bonds, etc., for safe custody in the Bank's fire-proof strong-rooms, and the Bank will attend to the collection of the coupons and drawn bonds so deporited as they fall due.
Mercantile credits issued.
Annuities, pensions, dividends, etc., collected.
All farther particulars and information can be obtained on application.
The officers and clerks of the Bank are pledged to secrecy as to the transactions of customers. 18-9-905

div.head: DAILY WEATHER REPORT
div.p: OBSERVATIONS BY THE SURVEY DEPARTMENT.
REMARKS.

From 8 a.m. up to noon of yesterday the weather remained boisterous, very squally, with frequent heavy showers from the N.W. and a rough sea. It gradually abated and gave place to a light breeze and smoother sea, which continued throughout the night. Barometer still keeping steady.
At 7a.m. to-day a heavy shower passed over Abdul Abbas district, but none over the Kom-el-Nadoura Observatory.

For the 24 hours ending 8 a.m. Yesterday

div.p: THE PLANETS,
Mercury is too near the Sun in the early part of the month to be visible, becoming an evening star later.
Venus is an evening star setting about two hours after the Sun.
Mars rises about 2.30 a.m. and shines as a morning star. Jupiter is to be seen in the South about 10 p.m. and sets. about 4 p.m.
Saturn souths about 7 p.m. and sets at midnight.
The chief constellations in the south at 9 p.m. are Andromeda and Pegasus near the zenith, Cetus about 50 deg, and Sculptor about 30 deg. above the horizon.

div.head: THE BALTIC FLEET.
div.p: According to a telegram from London to day, the negotiations between Great Britain and Russia in regard to what has been de- scribed by Lord Rosebery as the "unspeakable outrage" of the Russian Baltic Fleet, are pro- gressing. The commission which is to study the matter will probably consist of an admital and a legal adviser on both sides, together with naval officers belonging to neutrals. Great Britain is in favour of Paris, and Russia of The Hague, as the place for the meeting. Other essential points require the most careful consi- deration. Meanwhile, we are told, the Russian fleet will probably be thousands of miles away before the enquiry even begins. This does not

contains pure Carbolic Acid (healing and antiseptic) and other useful ingredients to cure or alleviate sunburn, chafed skin, piles, cuts, burns, insect bites, &c.

sound satisfactory, but we have sufficient confidence in the Government to believe that every guarantee has been received that the fleet will no longer constitute a menace to our shipping. We are content to await the results of the enquiry with calm and dignified patience. The attitude of England has, indeed, throughout been characterised with admirable calmness. The outrage touched us vitally. The offence was not only one against the lives of English. men, it was an outrage committed on the high seas against the nation which claims to rule the waves. Nothing could so stir the country as an atrocity which touches a maritime people in so sensitive a spot, and nothing could seem more dastardly to English ideas than a coward- ly attack, whether deliberate or unpremeditated, upon unarmed and defenceless men. Had the fishermen been French, or of any other nationality, our indignation would scarcely have been less, though our personal honour would not have been involved. The measure of our anger's depth, and the measure of our de-1 termination, may be taken by the calmness we continue to display. It is a dangerous calm, symptomatic of feelings that are too deep and sacred for words or demonstration. It is earnestly to be hoped that it is properly understood abroad, and especially at St. Petersburg. For any misapprehension which confuses patience with pusillanimity, or moderation with readiness to allow this outrage to be passed over as other outrages, almost as "unspeakable," have been, will as surely lead to disaster as that obstirate defiance by Russia of which perturbing signals have not been lacking. There. is no shred of division or irresolution in Great and Greater Britain. Never before has the country been so absolutely one. If quarrel we must have we have that quarrel just, and once in we will so bear ourselves that others may beware of us. Our conscience acquits us of bellicose or Chauvinistic impatience. We have borne ourselves like men in our treatment of an unparalleled situation. We still earnestly hope that our moderation and dignity will be rewarded as they deserve. But if it fall out otherwise, we shall bear ourselves like men to the bitter end, strong in the justice of our cause

div.head: THE WAR.
div.p: The only war news we have to-day is contained in a telegram from Tokio reporting a tremendous bombardment of Port Arthur, the fall of which is said to be near at hand. Meantime, all is quiet in Manchuria, though we may hear at any time that the Japanese have resumed the offensive. The annals of scientific warfare would be vainly searched for any tactical position re- sembling that of the two vast armies now facing one another between Liao-yang and Mukden. For fully two weeks, each of these immense forces has virtually stood at bay, challenging the other to come on. Pretty equally matched in numbers and pugnacity, they only wait for an order to rush at the foe, and obedience will be rendered with all possible alacrity. But Marshal Oyama and General Kuropatkin are concerned with matters of higher moment from their respective standpoints. It was the Russian late effort to march south, to relieve Port Arthur, which influenced the Japanese commander to replace offensive strategy by defensive. Similarly, it was the Japanese impetuous northerly advance that constrained Kuropatkin, after the failure of his attempt to get south, to halt on the Sha-ho. In the one case, the object is the capture of Port Arthur by starvation and storm combined before relief arrives; in the other, the Russians feel them- selves bound to retain possession of Mukden. at any cost. In effect, it is a game of patience, and it only remains to be seen which side will be the first to give way to irritation at the delay.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE
div.p: The Khedive inspected his estates yesterday at Mariout, and returned in the evening to Montazah palace, where he is spending today. The Gonvernorat of Cairo has issued invitations to numerous officials and notables to present themselves at the station at 11.30 a.m. next Tuesday to greet his Highness on his arrival. The Ministry of War has given orders for a detachment to be present as a guard of. The train in which his Highness travels will stop at Damanhour, Tantah, (Buket el) San, and Benha.

div.head: LEGISLATIVE COUNCIL.-
div.p: The next meeting of the Legislative Council is not expected to take place before December 1.

div.head: AMERICAN MISSION.-
div.p: The English services in Tantal under the auspices of the American Mission will be resumed next Sabbath, 6th inst., at 11 am, and will be held as formerly at once every two weeks

div.head: SHOOTING OUTRAGE.
div.p: The director of the sugar factory at Bileh has been fired at and slightly wounded while standing by his window in the evening. A dissatisfied or dismissed workman is believed to have been guilty of the crime.

div.head: NEW LINER.
div.p: Another new steamer (called the Bores, a sister ship to the Milo) for the Bell's Asia Minor SS. Company, arrived at Alexandria from Hall and the Syrian Coast yesterday. She is commanded by Capt. J. McLaren, this being the second steamer which he has brought out from home.

div.head: PROFITABLE PASTIME-
div.p: It is not only the wish to learn quickly which urges so many to go to the Berlitz Schools, but also the prospect of taking an hour's lesson in the most agreeable way. For example, many ladies take lessons simply for pleasure, a very useful pastime. A trial lesson in English, French, or any other language may be had at Alexandria, 26, Rue Eglise Copte, or at Cairo, 1, Sharia Kamel. [ADVT.)

div.head: THE PYRAMID-
div.p: Visitors to the Pyramids will be pleased to learn that an attempt is being made to meet the requirements of the "inner man" in this locality. A bar and restaurant have been opened where tea, etc., can be obtained at moderate prices. All the refreshments are supplied by Mr. Spathis, the well- known merchant and mineral water manufacturer, and this is a sufficient guarantee of their high quality.

div.head: THE NEW NORDEUTSCHER LLOYD
div.p: 'Imperial Mail steamer Prinz Eitel Friedrick, a description of which we gave in a recent issue, lett Suez yesterday morning, bound to China. She had a full first and second-class passenger list, which includes 17 naval officers, 32 cadets, and 10 non-commissioned officers, reliefs for the German squadron in the Far East. There t were also on board 17 Belgian soldiers in charge of an officer, bound for China.

div.head: H.M. TRANSPORT
div.p: Soudan (Capt. S. de B. Lockyer, R.N.R.) arrived at Port Said on Tuesday from Bombay for Malta and Southampton. There were 1,362 of all ranks on board, including the Cheshire Regiment, num- bering 427 officers and men, who are to be stationed at Lichfield on their arrival in England. Sixty-nine details are to land at Malta. The officer commanding the troops is Lt. Col. Hardy, Cheshire Regt.

div.head: COQUELIN AINE
div.p: Coquelin Ainé makes his debut at the Zizinia Theatre to-morrow evening in Molière's comedy Tartufe, in which he will play the title role.

It will be interesting if we give a few particulars of the great French actor's life. Coquelin Ainé is the son of a baker, and was destined originally to follow that trade; but evincing a great aptitude for the stage, he went to Paris and was admitted to the Conservatoire on December 29, 1859, joining M. Regnier's class, of which he became the most brilliant pupil. He obtained the second prize for comedy, and made his debut at the Théâtre Français on December 7, 1860, in the character of Gros-René in the "Dépit Amoureux." He afterwards played with success in the "Fourberies de Scapin," "Mariage de Figaro," "Don Juan," and other classical pieces; Lupin in "La Mère Confideute; the Marquis in "Le Joueur;" Annibal in "L'Aventurière," &c. He created the role of Anatole in "Une Loge d'Opera," John in Trop Curieux," Gagneux in "Jean Baudry," Vincent in "L'Eillet Blanc," Aristide in "Le Lion Amoureux," Gringoire in the play of that name, Beaubourg in "Paul Forestier," Eucrate in "Le Coq de Mycille," &c. M. Coquelin has obtained great success in society by reciting in private and at public meetings, and has thus added to the reputation of new poets, particularly of Eugène Ma nuel and François Coppée. In 1886 he was put on the list of "societaires pensionnaires" of the Theatre Français, and this prevented him from appearing as an actor in any French theatre. But, after travelling abroad in America and Alsace at the head of a dramatic company of his own formation, he reentered the Comedie Française in December, 1889, and played Mascarille, Diafoirus, and Argente, and other parts, in order to support his son Jean, at that time making his first appearances as an actor. He created the part of Labussière in M. Sardou's Thermidor, which after three representations was interdicted by the French Government (January 25, 1891). His next creation was Petruccio in a modified version of the "Taming of the Shrew" (Nov. 1892). As his engagement at the Theatre Français lasts only six months each year, he has recently taken to touring abroad with a company of his own selection, and in the summer of 1892 he brought "Thermi dor" and "La Megère Apprivoisée" to London. He is the author of several works on the comedian's art.

div.head:
THE KOM OMBO CO.
A GREAT UNDERTAKING.
div.p: We have been favoured with some interest- ing details regarding the progress being made by the Kom Ombo Company, which is engaged 1 in undertaking the development of the great plain extending from the Nile to Gebel Silsileh The undertaking is financed by Sir Ernest Cassel and Messrs. Suares and Cattaui. The t concession extends to 120,000 feddans, with the option of taking up another 40,000 feddans at a slightly higher level, which is now about to be surveyed.
A correspondent, writing on the subject,

The work which is now being done at Kom Ombo is one of the most important undertakings which has ever been attempted in this country. The Suez Canal and the Assouan Dam may take precedence of it, but, for my part, I have no objection to stating that the work now being taken in hand at Kom Ombo is fully entitled to take the third place. Nobody, who has not visited and personally inspected the works, can have the slightest conception of their magnitude and of the enormous task, which has been undertaken in order to make this huge desert plain at smiling area of cultivated land. It is a great pity that the disaster of last year, when the pamping building tumbled down, should have greatly impeded the work. At present the pumping installation is being rapidly developed. The levelling of the land, the making of canals, the laying of the piping, and the many other odd jobs, necessitated by such a gigantic undertaking, are being rapidly brought to completion to enable crops to be grown at an early date. No less than four thousand men are now engaged on the work. One of the most remarkable portions of the work is the pumping installation. Vast shops have been erected for the pumps and all the other kinds of mechanical works. Birch Bey is the great organiser and manager of this property. From the conversation which I had with him, he appeared to be quite satisfied with the progress that is being made and he stated that he had no doubt but that Sir Ernest Cassel would be equally satisfied.

div.head: MENZALEH CANAL & NAVIGATION CO.
div.p: The powerful new dredger for the Menzaleh Canal and Navigation Company has now been built, and it is expected that it will be at work in about a week's time. The order for the fleet of this company has been placed in the hands of the Anglo-American Nile Steamer and Hotel Company, who are charged with the whole of the order. The fleet will consist of six barges, two passenger steamers, and two tugs, and all these vessels will be built in England. They will be delivered by June 1, 1905. By that date it is hoped to open a portion of the canal (30 kilomètres) between Matarich and Port Said. This will be a great advantage for passengers. The Belgian company which has a light railway in this part of the Delta will run a service of specially quick trains from Mansourah to Matarieh in connection with the boats of the Menzaleh Company. The time occupied on the journey from Matarieh to Port Said will thus be shortened to five hours. The immense possibilities for the development of the Sharkieh Province owing to this rapid communication are obvious.

div.head: PORT SAID DEVELOPMENT
div.p: New Harbour Works

At the end of last year the Suez Canal Company invited tenders for making two new basins on the Asiatic side of Port Said harbour, one of which was to accommodate the colliers that discharge there and the other the petroleum tank steamers.

Among the numerous tenders received from all parts of Europe, that sent in by the Société de Grands Travaux de Marseille was accepted. Including the additional or supplementary works that the Canal Company will carry out itself, the total cost of constructing these two new basins will amount to about three million frames, or £120,000. Once these basins are completed, that now known as the "Bassin Abbas," near the waterworks, on the African side, will be utilized for steamers generally, other than the colliers which at present use it exclusively.

The Suez Canal Company intends likewise to considerably improve the two other basins, known by the names of the Bassin de l'Arsenal and the Bassin Chérif, on the same side of the shore, by enlarging and deepening them and adapting or making them available also for cargosteamers of the largest tonnage and draught. As a result of these improvements and changes the general workshops will have to be removed elsewhere. They will, at the same time, be much enlarged, remodelled, and improved. After a long study of this question the chief engineer of the company, now in Paris, recommended that the new buildings should be erected on the Asiatic side of the harbour, opposite the town, where sufficient space is available, and at this moment a definite project is before the directors for their approval.

On the other hand, a short time back the Canal Company imported three large porteurs, floating receivers or mud tanks, which are used, in connection with the powerful marine dredgers in the port. To increase the dredging operations necessary to keep the port at a uniform and requisite depth, the company has ordered another steamer dredger and mud tank combined, of the type known as the Puissante Of the new floating dock recently arrived at Port Said from England we have already given a description.

div.head:
MURDER IN A THEATRE
A DASTARDLY OUTRAGE
div.p: About 10.30 p.m., whilst the performance was going on, the ticket-collector was seen to rush into the auditorium closely pursued by the man in charge of the box-office, of Greek nationality, who carried a dagger in his hand. The latter fell upon his victim and inflicted a deep wound in the back, from which the man fell in front of the stage. He attempted to rise and escape, but was furiously attacked twice and fell dying at the side entrance of the theatre, leaving a trail of blood behind him. The audience, panic-striken, rushed to the exits of the theatre, and it was left to the fireman on duty to effect the capture of the murderer. The latter seized his belt axe and felled the man to the ground near his dying victim. The murderer, however, escaped the clutches of the fireman and was finally arrested as he emerged into the open street by the ghafir on duty on a sign from the fireman, who blew his whistle.
The man so brutally attacked, who is an Italian, was removed to the Greek Hospital, but expired on the way. His assassin has been incarcerated at Labbane caracol pending his trial.
The motive of the crime has not as yet transpired, but it evidently arose from a violent quarrel which the two men had at the entrance of the theatre.

div.head:
PRINCE MOHAMED IBRAHIM.
ARRESTED FOR "SCORCHING."
div.p: The curious experience of having before him as defendant a member of a reigning house (says the Globe) has befallen the district magistrate of the French Commune of Tartas. A tourist had been stopped on the highway for driving a motor car at excessive speed, and on being brought before the magistrate proved to be Prince Mohamed Ibrahim of Egypt. A small fine was inflicted.

div.head: COUNCIL OF MINISTERS
div.p: The next meeting of the Council of Ministers has been put off till after the arrival of H.H. the Khedive in Cairo.

div.head: VISIT OF GREEK FLEET.
div.p: The members of the Khedivial Yacht Club will be "at home" to the officers of the Greek Fleet at the clubhouse on Wednesday next from 3 to 6 pm, when special races will be held.

div.head: KING'S BIRTHDAY
div.p: (November 9.)
There will be the usual official reception at the Consulate during the forenoon.
In the afternoon the Consul-General and Mrs. Gould will be "at home" from 3.30 to 6.30.

div.head: PLAGUE AT SMYRNA.
div.p: In consequence of two suspicious cases of plague having been discovered at Smyrna on the 29th ulto, arrivals at Constantinople from that port are subject to a medical examination.

div.head: NEW BOOK ON THE NILE
div.p: Sir William Willocks' new book on the Nile is in the press and will be published at the end of this month.
Sir William's leave commenced on Tuesday. He intends spending it on the Nile.

div.head: DEATH OF ARABIC SCHOLAR.
div.p: The Morning Post of last Friday says: We regret to announce that Professor H. Anthony Salmoné, Professor of Arabic at King's College, London, died at his residence, 47, Powis-square, from apoplexy. Of Cretan parentage, he was born in Beyrout in 1860 and educated in the university of that city. Soon after coming to this country he was appointed professor of Arabic at University College, Lon don, and in 1890 he received the appointment of professor at King's College. In the same year he published an important Arabic-English and English-Arabic Lexicon in two volumes and received a gratifying acknowledgment of his work from the Sultan, who sent him the Order of the Modji-lich of the Third Class in re- cognition of the services he had rendered to Oriental literature. For many years Professor Salmoné, by his addresses and writings, laboured to draw attention to the necessity of encouraging Oriental studies in Great Britain, and he contributed miscellaneous articles to the reviews and newspapers, including the Morning Post. He published in 1896 a book on "The Fall and Resurrection of Turkey," and devised and edited "The Imperial Souvenir," an in- teresting work which was dedicated by special permission to Queen Victoria. It gives a metrical translation of the third verse of the National Anthem in fifty languages spoken in the British Empire.

div.head: THE CAIRO ROADS.
div.p: Since the 3rd October traffic has been stopped on that portion of the Attaba el Khadra leading from the entrance to the Mohamed Aly-street to the beginning of the Mousky. The shopkeepers have suffered very greatly from this interruption to the traffic. It was officially estimated that the barricade would only last for three days, but it continued from the 3rd October until Monday last, when the work was practically finished. The labourers did their best to prolong the job, and the interests of the merchants and the retail traders in the neighbourhood have suffered very greatly.

div.head:
THE EVE OF THE SEASON.
A HINT TO TRAVELLERS.
div.p: We are on the eve of the season, and all the steamers going East are depositing passengers booked for Egypt and the Nile. Some of these are visiting this country for the first time, others are old habitués, among whom are several who are coming to visit the country again after the lapse of many years. The following information will doubtless be of service to many of these.

Society people who come for social pleasures, and who soon tire of Egyptology and sight- seeing, will find one of the new hotels, luxuriously built and equipped to meet all modern requirements (such as the Savoy, Ghezireh Palace, the Continental, or Shepheard's) will afford them a comfortable resting place. But there is another section of the community to be reckoned with and provided for. It is composed of people who are travellers in the true sense; whose object in visiting Cairo is to see all the objects of antique interest-not at a breakneck pace and because they must "get through,"-but in their own way, and who con- template during the winter a long series of lei- surely and reverent ruminations amid the actual scenes made familiar to them in the course of laborious study. Such persons would find the fashionable life and circumstances of the large hotels distinctly distasteful, not to say jarring. But the scientific traveller and studious person is not uncatered for; the Hotel du Nil has always been his headquarters and remains his proper "locale".

It may very probably be news to many who have thought they knew Cairo, that the Hotel du Nil stands 3 metres higher than the Esbekich and the hotels in that quarter. The house is an irregular square in Moorish architecture. Its picturesque character may be taken for granted when it is said that the bedrooms, of which there are 100, open on to verandahs on the ground floor, and on the first floor on to a charming balcony which rans round two of the inner sides of the courtyard. The aspect of the hotel is full South, and its position is sheltered. Moreover, the building has none of the heavy character which is given by much marble, even when it is white in colour.

One has greater warmth, therefore, during the winter at the Hotel du Nil than when located elsewhere in Cairo. One terrace only is marble-paved, and on this the person who wishes a quiet sun-bath may sit and study removed from all the sounds of the town, while) in the middle of it, and commanding a six-acre extent of open ground, is the garden of the Grand Moofty. The observatory tower on the highest terrace commands a most magnificent view. The hole of the city to its farthest circumference (for the Hotel du Nil occupies its mathematical centre) is spread around on all sides. The slender minaret of the Mosque Adi Yehish is the beautiful object close at hand that one notices against the blue sky, in this air, which is certainly as fresh as any in Cairo. The Mohamed Aly Mosquestands out well on the city's edge with the Mokattam Hills in the rear, and the Pyramids of Ghizeh and even of Sakarah are comprehended also in the wonderful view. The entrance is on the Khalig, a new, broad roadway opening out from the Mousky; the dining room has windows on three sides, there are two coffee-rooms, and three pleasant salons where refuge and coolness from the midday sunshine and glare of the terrace is acceptable. Breakfast and tea, and in fact any meal at the pleasure of visitors, may be taken in the kiosks in the courtyard, where bananas, date palms, and a banyan afford a green repose for the eyes. The hotel has a dark-room for photographers, a billiard room and bar, bath rooms, and an additional room which is fitted with a very complete douche apparatus. The manage- ment and cooking at the Hotel du Nil are excellent, and the major domo is one of the best-known and most respected men in Cairo, always most successful in making his guests happy and comfortable.

In the early days of the Hotel du Nil, Cairo had no Ismailia, no Tewfikieh, no Doabara quarters. It was Mousky, Mousky, and always Mousky, and for the whole of one's sojourn in Cairo then, as now at the. Nil, whether in the house or out of it, one felt one's self to be really in the East. A foreigner who was com paring his impressions of some European cities the other day was heard to say, "London it is grand, Paris it is magnifique, but Gothenburg- I like it In the same way the verdict of many old habitués of Egypt who come again and again to stay in Cairo is-Shepheard's it is grand, the Savoy it is magnificent, but the Hotel du Nil-I like it.

div.head: FISHERY LAW.
div.p: An Order of the Finance Ministry, issued yesterday, states that as from the 1st January, 1905, the Fishery Law of 1903 shall apply to the Suez Canal. The tariff for boats fishing in the Canal will be that prescribed for Egyptian maritime waters.
The same law will apply to Lake Mariout as from the same date.

div.head: RAILWAY CARRIAGES.
div.p: We understand that the Metropolitan Amal- gamated Railway Carriage and Wagon Company of Birmingham have obtained the contract for the supply of carriages for the Egyptian Railway Administration.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Ellerman 89. City of Khios mailed yesterday direct for Liverpool with passengers and general cargo, intlading 6.317 bales cotton The S.S. Ocean Prince le Antwerp on Wednesday, with passengers and general cargo for Malla and Alexandria.
The S.S. Castilian Prince left for Manchester on Tuesday, with general cargo, consisting of 8,550 bales cotton.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA MUNICIPALITY
div.p: Owing to the absence of a "quorum," the town councillors' meeting did not take place yesterday. As for three months people have been waiting anxiously for the members to return, in order that various affairs in suspenso might be settled, this inaction on the part of our civic representatives demands explanation. Por three consecutive sittings there has not been a "quorun" and decisions have had to be come to by only a few members at a subsequent meeting. This was the case on the 16th July, 16th October, and it will be the case for the next sitting of the Commission.
We have received the following communication, with a request for its insertion-
APATHY OF TOWN COUNCIL 26 MEMBERS IN Town.
A BURNING QUESTION ON TAPIS.
Yesterday as well as October 12 no quorum, ie, twice within one month. At present I compare our meetings to a friendly social gathering.

4 p.m. is the nominal hour, but those who trouble themselves to be punctual may just wait till a sufficient number to form a quorum saunter in, sometimes this is from 30 to 45 minutes, others after an hour waiting.
As yesterday, those who have now wasted their whole afternoon are allowed to go, being total no quorum come again Monday.
If the Press were admitted and those sort of things pressed upon the public they might. not occur so often as twice in one month. Yours obediently,
GEO. B. ALDERSON.

div.head: PHARMACY REGULATIONS.
div.p: The following notice has been issued by the Sanitary Administration:

"Pharmacists and all persons, desiring to obtain an authorisation to sell drugs and poisonous substances are informed that the Sanitary Administration holds at their disposal in its offices at Cairo and all the gouvernorats, moudiriehs, and beadquarters of districts, model registers and labels which pharmacists are bound to use by Articles 6, 8, 16,17, and 18 of the decree of December 15, 1904, relating to the management of pharmacies and the sale of poisonous drugs.

"Pharmacists who hold licenses to sell poisonous substances according to the decree of 1891 are informed that new licenses must be obtained within ninety days from the publica- tion of the decree, as the licenses which they have previously held become null and void on and after December 21"..
The notice also contains details of the examination which must be passed by all vendors of poisonous substances in accordance with the new regulations.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: Lady Ads Hervey Bathurst and her son will arrive at Mens House Hotel this evening and will stay there for a month before proceeding up the Nile. They arrived at Port Said by the Orient Liner Onnal this morning.
Lady Goldie Taubman is coming to Mena House Hotel next month, and will stay over Christmas.
Judge Vere: Alston, of the Native Court of Appeal, and Mrs. Alston will make a long stay at Mena House Hotel this season, while their new residence at Ghezireh is being built.
Mr. Cotton Fox, who has been a regular visitor to Mena House Hotel for some years past, arrives there on the 15th inst.
Mr. Wright-Henderson, another regular visitor at Mena House Hotel, arrived there to-day.
Sir Augustus and Lady Hemming are going to stay all the winter at Mena.

Among the passengers who disembarked at Port Said on Tuesday afternoon from the P. and 0. S.S. Egypt were Mrs. Mellwraith, e, Mrs. Wilson, wife of Colonel Wilson, Rifle Brigade, and daughter, Mrs. and Miss Allan Joseph, and Mr. E. H. Harrison, general manager of Messrs. Thos. Cook and Son.
Saba Pasha, the Postmaster-General, left Cairo yesterday evening for Alexandria.
M. Barois is expected to arrive in Caire next Friday.
Mr. Tottenham will shortly accompany Mr. Dupuis to the Sudan.

The Rev. A. Livingstone left Cairo yesterday to resume his duties in Cyprus. Professor Dr. E. Schirmer, a very distinguished physician from Marburg, Germany has arrived at "Al Hayat" for a prolonged stay.
Geheimer Regierungirath, Dr. Meyer and Fran Meyer are expected at "Al Hayat" tomorrow from Shepheard's Hotel.
Mr. R. S. Patterson, from the Ministry of Public Instruction, has been appointed inspector to the Department of Direct Taxation, Ministry of Finance

div.head: EGYPTIAN SHARE MARKET.
div.p: As we anticipated in our issue of last week, there has been a sharp rally in Agricultural Bank shares, which have risen to 10 1/2. There has been large buying during the last few days which came from a well-informed source, and the supply of shares on the Market here is limited. National Bank shares have reacted a little after touching 23 1/4, but are still a remarkably firm market at 22 1/2, the new shares standing at 6 1/4 premium. A feature yesterday was a rise of 1/2 in Delta Preferred to 15 1/2. In spite of the tension caused by the political situation of the last few days, the market in Egyptian Stocks has held firm, in fact more than that, prices have advanced, which cannot be said of any other section of the Stock Markets. It is a marked sign of the strength of the market for Egyptian securities that it should be able to cut itself adrift from such a general and strong depression as affected all other securities yesterday. Buyers always take up and pay for their purchases, consequently there is no weak Bull element – such as in the highly speculative markets who easily take fright, in a crisis such as we are passing through just now, and are accustomed to sell as eagerly as they before bought. At the closing of the mail, I learn on high authority that before many hours are over the Russian trouble will be settled to our satisfaction; due in no small measure to the fact that all the financial concerns in Paris are up to their necks in Russian securities. Very important news has also just reached Russia from Port Arthur, which may have a serious bearing on their attitude towards England at the present moment.

div.head: THE COTTON MARKET
div.p: KEARSLEY AND CUNNINGHAM'S WEEKLY REPORT
Liverpool, October 27.
The demand for Egyptian Cotton has been very limited this week, and owing to the scarcity of the current qualities, quotations must be considered quite nominal.
Only a moderate business has been done in "Futures," the following, however, are the closing quotations-

American Futures. The market this week has been generally dull in tone, although there have been frequent fluctuations, and prices have had a declining tendency. Today's closing values are 5 @ 8 points lower than those of last Thursday. Crop movements continue large, and there is a disposition to somewhat increase the estimates of yield, 11 millions being probably the most generally accepted figure, although estimates as high as 12 millions are by no means uncommon. For the moment, at any rate, there seems to be too much cotton moving to make any decided upward movement in prices likely. There have been the usual reports of killing frosts from several sections of the cotton area, but they have failed to arouse more than momentary interest. During the last day or two, political anxiety has overshadowed the market, and at the moment of writing is still the predominating influence. The latest quotations are, delivery:-
P.S – Owing to reports of a more favourable political situation the market closed firm at a recovery of 45 points.

div.head: BOULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (Aujourd'hui à midi et demi)

Le marché des valeurs reste calme et inactif, parce que c'est aujourd'hui le dernier jour des Liquidations de fin du mois. Les seuls titres qui aient donné lieu à quelque mouvement sont la Ramleh Railway et les Faux d'Alexandrie. Il y a hausse sur la Banque Nationale à 23 1/8, sur la Nungovich à 8 15/16, sur les Faux du Caire à 965, sur les Tramways d'Alexandrie à 144 les Privilégiées et 374 les Divi- dendes.
Ilya baisse, au contraire, sur l'Agricole à 10 3/4, la Béhéra à 53 1/4, la Salt & Soda à 28 et la Delta à 15 1/4.
Le cours des Eaux d'Alexandrie a atteint 16 7/16 dans la matinée, mais en clôture on a fléchi à 16 1/4, soit 3/4 de hausse sur le prix d'hier.
Quant à la Ramleb, elle monte de 8 1/2 à 9/16 vendeurs.

div.head:
MR. DUPUIS' REPORT.
THE GASH SCHEME
div.byline: By Sir Hanbury Brown, K.C.M.G., late Inspector General of Irrigation in Lower Egypt, and formerly in Upper Egypt.
div.p: As we have now concluded the case for the Blue Nile, we pass on to the consideration of Mr. Dupuis’ proposals relating to the river Gash.

The river Gash project consists of a scheme for storing and controlling the water of that river, and using it in the irrigation of the country about Kassala. This river is peculiar in that it finally disappears in the sands.

Mr. Dupuis' report describes the river Gash as issuing from the Abyssinian hills on to the Sudan plains in the form of a wide, shallow, sandy torrent on much the same level as the plains themselves. As far as Kassala the river is confined to its channel, but below) Kassala it begins to spill over its banks, the spills becoming more numerous and continuous, with several fairly large and defined channels amongst them, with the result that 6 or 7 miles from Kassals the river channel has dwindled away to nothing. The spill leaves a thick mud deposit, on which large areas of durra are cultivated. The water flows forward from 50 to 100 miles in more or less ill-defined channels, irrigating large areas of grazing ground and 6 patches of cultivation. These channels tend to unite and grow deeper again, becoming fewer in number, until one only is left, which eventually loses itself in a sandy desert tract to the north of the village of Fillik.

The Gash flows for only about eighty days in the year, coming down early in July and drying up in the latter part of September. Throughout the remainder of the year the river bed is absolutely dry. Mr. Dupuis is of the opinion that the ordinary flood discharge of the Gash does not often exceed 5,000,000 cubic meters a day. At the Kassala ford the channel t is 250 m. wide, and the flood depth about 50 cm.

The Gash is given to troublesome vagaries, in consequence of which the cultivated areas and grazing grounds shift about and the t wells are affected, involving migrations of the population and a feeling of insecurity, with other disadvantages.
To remedy this and introduce stable conditions, Mr. Dupuis recommends the following scheme-

“If works can be constructed on any scale, it would seem that what is required is a large circular basin enclosing the tract about the delta head, into which the river would be guided by small retaining banks running some little distance up the main river on either side. The river would be received into this basin and allowed to overflow and spread about in the area enclosed, throwing down the greater portion of its heavy silt just as it does at present, and passing off through several regulators in the surrounding bank. Until the end of the flood the regulators in this bank would not be used to a greater extent than was necessary to secure the partition of the water in the way desired, so that existing conditions would be but very slightly disturbed. At the end of the flood, when the river began to fall, the regulators would be closed and the whole basin give a last thorough soaking, and the stored water could then be run off and utilised lower down. The various regulators would form the heads of different canals, or might feed a second system of basins forming a more or less concentric ring round the first circular basin, or one or more of them might be used merely as escapes to pass away excess of water forward down the existing lines of flow.”
The idea requires developing after more information has been collected. The advantage of the scheme is that it can be carried out progressively and tentatively so as to profit by actual experience.

There is much to recommend something being done in this direction, for, as Mr. Dupuis reports, the agricultural possibilities of the Gash area in Kassala Moudirieh cannot fail to strike any visitor interested in such matters; the fertility of the soil is unquestionable, and there is no doubt as to the former prosperity of the country. Nothing, he writes, could give a greater impetus to the restoration of the district than works for the control of the Gash flood, by means of which definite conditions could be guaranteed to definite tracts of country. Lord Cromer, in his covering dispatch, places the Gash project first in order of importance of the irrigation works intended to benefit the Sudan, though Sir W. Garstin places it after the Wad Medani barrage and Gheritel canals. For the Gash project Sir William estimates the cost at LE: 500,000, and the revenue from land tax (on 100,000 acres at P.T. 50 an acre) at L.E. 50,000. Between the Gash and the Blue Nile runs the Athara River through "a vast plain of rich Hack soil sloping gently north-westwards from the foot of the Abyssinian hills on the south- east, which corresponds with the Abyssinian frontier."
"The enormous area of these plains, their
uniform level, and their extreme fertility, at once suggest the introduction of canals and Irrigation as a remedy for their waterless and waste condition."
(To be continued.)

div.head:
THE STATE OF HELOUAN
THE WATER SUPPLY.
div.p: In a preceding article we voiced the complaints of the people of Helouan on the subject of the deplorable state of their roads and of the complete indifference displayed by the Tanzim Department towards their grievances. But the complaints of the inhabitants of Helouan against the Tanzim Department are just as loud owing to the water supply. The water of Helonas is taken from the Nile and pumped into a reservoir. But owing to the development of Helouan towards the East, that part of the town, being at a higher altitude, can get very little water, and sometimes none during the day, because of the low pressure. Some- times the inhabitants of East Helouan have to wait until nightfall in order to fill their cisterns for the next day's supply. On many days throughout the year the water fails entirely in this part of Helouan. The quantity of the water is insufficient because the reservoir is too low or else there is a defect in the arrange- ment of the pipes. The reservoir and the water supply are in the hands of the Tanzim Department. Several complaints have been made to the officials of that Department on the subject of the pressure question, but no notice is taken.

If the quantity of the water affords grounds for complaint, the quality is an even greater grievance. The colour of the water is that of thick, yellowish, liquid mud. It is impossible to take a bath, as the water is not merely of a most repulsive colour, but quite filthy. The water is served out in the same state as it arrives from the river. There is no attempt at filtration whatsoever. Since the last cholera outbreak the Government has given grants to many centres of population throughout Egypt for the purpose of improving the water supply. At Helouan an attempt at boring for wells was made, but no good water was found. This was the only attempt made, and since the failure of the boring the Government has done nothing to improve the water supply. Yet Helouan is the only watering place in Egypt and every year attracts more and more visitors from every part of the world. Thousands and thousands of pounds have been sunk in hotels, sanatoria, baths, pensions, palaces and villas, and the population of the town is rapidly increasing. What makes the matter worse is that taxes have been introduced into Helouan within the last two years, and the Government thereby draws L.E. 3,000 from the town. But since the taxes have been levied, no improve- ment in the administration of the town has been made and even such elementary necessities as roads and water are neglected.

div.head: TO THE EDITOR OF THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
div.p: Sir, I am sure the public of Helouan are deeply grateful to you for having set forth their complaints on the subject of the disgraceful state of our roads in to-day's issue. I myself have personally interviewed the officials of the Tanzim Department on the question of the defective supply of water and of the state of the Nile road, but no notice has been taken of my complaints except to say that no money was available. The local Commission says the same and does nothing. Recently I sent two registered letters to the president of the local Commission asking that gentleman to give orders for a few lights to be effected on the road leading to our establishment. Neither of these letters received any attention, and the president did not even send a reply. This is a sample of the indifference which prevails among the members of the local Commission. The town ought not to be neglected as it is, for our roads and our water are both in a shameful state and it is essential that some steps should be taken to induce the Tanzim Department to improve the existing state of things.
I am, etc.,

div.head: BRITISH TRADE IN EGYPT
div.p: One of the most detrimental factors operating against the development of British trade in Egypt is the employment of foreign agents by English manufacturers to introduce their goods on the market. Some instructive examples of the state of things now prevailing have of late been brought to our notice. For instance, an agent at Cairo of a well-known Nottingham firm for a certain article in common use, is also an agent for a manufacturer of the same article on the Continent, who is one of his compatriots. In pushing the goods of the latter he invariably submits the samples of the former firm and points out how much cheaper the Continental manufacturer can produce an equivalent article. The unfairness of this system is obvious, for many of the English manufacturers are in many cases only known. to the local retailers through home introductions and representatives. Why should not English manufacturers endeavour to obtain British subjects resident in Egypt, who would take their interests far more to heart than do the existing foreign representatives, who have always their own axe to grind.

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY
div.p: Pending the outcome of the present crisis with Russia the departure of naval reliefs for the Mediterranean Fleet, the East Indies Squadron, and the China Squadron have been cancelled.
It has been decided that the headquarters and service squadrons of the 20th Hussars will be stationed at Brighton on its return from Cairo, and the reserve squadron at Canterbury.

The formal retirement of Lieutenant-Colonel W. II. Drage, D.8.0., Army Service Corps, who was so long and honourably associated with the Khedive's Army, has just taken place. He leaves the service with the best wishes of all who know him.

The command of the 1st Battalion Norfolk Regiment, which lately left Bareilly for Bloem- fontein, is vacant, Lieutenant-Colonel W. G. Hamilton, D.8.0., having accepted a staff billet in India. The step should go to Major Fitzgerald Wintour, who was transferred a year ago as second in command of the 1st Battalion - now at Colchester - from the 2nd Royal West Kents in Ceylon. He has four campaigns to his credit-Egyptian war 1882, Nile ex-. pedition 1884-85-86, Tochi expedition 1897, and the Boer war.

Recruiting for the Irish Guards has been re- opened and none but genuine "sons of the sod" are to be enlisted. A 2nd Battalion is to be added to the regiment if the recruits can be obtained, it is announced. If correct, it is rather curious that the Army Council with Mr. Arnold Forster's wild-cat scheme in view is adding to one end of the army whilst proposing to cut off several battalions at the other.

The order for the few 18-pounder field guns at Woolwich is being proceeded with as rapidly as possible, and in order to have the guns complete for use when finished the manu- facture of the ammunition has been begun. At Woolwich 20,000 181-lb shells are to be made, and a similar order for the 12 ½ -pounder quick- firing gun, with which the Royal Horse Artillery batteries are to be re-armed, has also been put in hand.

It has been officially announced that no reduction is to be made in the strength of the various British squadrons scattered over the globe. This statement is reassuring and it is needed at the present crisis.

div.head: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR.
div.p: Wo do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions expressed by our correspondents, but we wish, in a spirit n of fair play to all, to permit – within certain necessary limits – free discussion.

div.head: QUARANTINE FORMALITIES.
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.

Dear Sir, – My Bombay servant arrived at Suez on October 12 last by the Austrian Lloyd S.S. Imperator. His luggage was properly fumigated by the Government authorities, and he was discharged after signing the usual formal declaration as to his destination and definite address. He arrived at Alexandria promptly, and has been in my house constantly since.

On the 30th of October, eighteen days after his arrival, a representative of the Sanitary Department called to inquire concerning him, and I was told he might wish to see him later. On November 1, the same gentleman came to my house at the breakfast hour, and took my servant to Bacos station for examination for plague, twenty days after he was discharged from the ship.

There he was told to come for six days at the same hour for further examination. On my formal protest at such a ridiculous procedure, the resident doctor, who cannot be blamed for carrying out his orders, kindly agreed to visit my house for these six days.
Possibly some of your readers can explain who is responsible for this useless formality at this late date.
I am, etc.,

div.head: CAIRO OMNIBUSES.
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE

Sir,-In your remarks in yesterday's issue. regarding the present omnibuses, which areallow- ed to crawl about the streets of Cairo, you might have stated that it is probably on account of the "influential capitalists'' who compose the company that the 'buses are permitted to obstruct the traffic at their own sweet will. I lately remarked to a "shawish" on duty how extraordinary it seemed that he exercised control over all the remainder of the traffic while he permitted the buses to loiter about (near the Ateb-el-Khadra) often two and three abreast, as they wished. He instantly named two of the most influential officials in the country as partners in the bus company, and that consequently it would not pay a police- man to interfere. This impression, which has been successfully created among the City Police force, explains a good deal. Any persons who would care to see for themselves have only to drive (or, better, walk) down to the Ateb-el-Khadra-square at any hour of the day
I am, etc.,

div.head: STATE RAILWAYS.
To THE EDITOR OF THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.
div.p: Sir,-On the 31st ult. the 4.45 p.m. express to Alexandria started 20 minutes late; it did another very unusual thing at Toukh station, stayed there several minutes, and the consequence was it arrived at Tantah 32 minutes late. It will be interesting if any of your numerous readers can inform us why the train started late, why it stopped at Toukh, and lastly, what time the train arrived at Alexandria It had evidently pulled up 15 minutes loss of time passing here.
I am, etc.,

div.head: SAVOY HOTEL, ASSOUAN.
div.p: The Anglo-American Nile Steamer and Hotels Company, is greatly improving the Savoy Hotel at Assousn for the coming season. A fine lift has been erected and will be in working order by the end of this month. We may mention that the advance bookings at this hotel give every evidence of an excellent season at Assonan, and the Anglo-American Nile Steamer Company has a large number of tourists already on its books.

div.head: SAINT ANDREW'S FOOTBALL CLUB.
div.p: The committee of the above club is to be complimented on the excellent attendance at the general meeting called for Tuesday evening. Considering the adverse weather conditions, the number present was exceedingly gratifying, and augurs well for the olab's future. The chair was taken by the Bev. H.P. Reid, and in his opening remarks the chairman congratulated the club on the success attained daring initial season, and also referred to the round financial footing on which the new season was being commenced. Reference was made to the siffion sy of obtaining a ground more suitable than the present pitch on Moharram Bey common, but hopes are entertained thas a better playing pitch will be found in the course of the season. In the meantime she team will continue to play on the old ground. We are inclined to think that were a more inviting piece of ground acquired, the popularity of the club would be assured, but with the enthusiasm displayed by the members, the club has shown itself to be an institution well worthy of the support of the community.

The business of the evening included the election of offer-bearers for the new season. The Rev. Mr. Reid was unanimously re-elected president, and Mr. J. Davis Bryan vice-president, Mr. W. J. Webb was elected secretary, and Mr. Geo bwee treasurer. The subscription for playing members was fixed at PT. 60 and for honorary members a minimum of PT. 25 was decided upon.

Immediate steps are being taken for the drawing up of an attractive fixture card, and a Rales Com mite has also boca appointed to draft rules by which the club will be governed, and these rules will be issued only to all members. The team will meet for practice on Muharrem Bay man Eatonlays at 350, and it is hoped that there will be a representative gathering of the players and all others interested.
The meeting closed with a hearty vote of thanks" to the chairman.
